title:
An In Vitro and
In Vivo Study of Thyroid Disruption
of 1,2-Bis(2,4,6-tribromophenoxy)ethane (BTBPE)—A Novel Brominated
Flame Retardant
abstract:
The
novel brominated flame retardant, 1,2-bis(2,4,6-tribromophenoxy)ethane
(BTBPE), is an emerging environmental pollutant with undetermined
toxicity. We investigated how BTBPE causes thyroid endocrine disruption
with integrated in silico, in vitro, and in vivo assays. In yeast
two-hybrid and T-Screen assays, BTBPE interacted with zebrafish thyroid
hormone receptors with binding energies weaker than the TR agonist-3,3′,5-Triiodo-l-thyronine (T3), and disrupted thyroid function as a thyroid
receptor (TR) agonist. We examined the bioconcentration, developmental
toxicity, and thyroid endocrine disruption in zebrafish after a 14-day
exposure to BTBPE (1, 3, 10 μg/L). Thyroxine (T4) was lower
in BTBPE-treated larvae, whereas corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH)
and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) were higher. The gene transcription
alterations along the hypothalamic-pituitary-thyroid (HPT) axis were
observed. Furthermore, reduced locomotion suggested that BTBPE imparts
developmental neurotoxicity at zebrafish early developmental stage.
Establishing that BTBPE has thyroid endocrine-disrupting effects is
an important step for understanding and managing BTBPE toxicity.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.text:
The manufacture and use
of primary legacy brominated flame retardants
(BFRs), e.g., polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs), have been limited
worldwide and novel brominated flame retardants (NBFRs) have replaced
them. Increased use of 1,2-bis (2,4,6-tribromophenoxy) ethane (BTBPE),
a typical NBFR, has created widespread environmental contamination.1,2 It has been detected in air,3 dust,4 soils,5 sediments,6 sludge, and surface water.7 Due to their highly hydrophobicity, BTBPE is seldom analyzed
in surface water and up to 5.22 ng/L has been reported.8 However, like PBDEs, BTBPE shows environmental
persistence and potential for bioaccumulation.1,9 It
is present in mud carp (Cirrhinus molitorella) (518
± 277 ng/g l.w.), crucian carp (Carassius auratus) (332 ± 315 ng/g l.w.),10 and shark
livers (up to 16.7 ng/g l.w.).11 BTBPE
has been shown in the food web of the South China Sea tropics.12 It has been detected in breast milk13 and human serum.14 The widespread presence of BTBPE indicates the need for the study
of its environmental effects and potential toxicity. Thyroid
hormones (THs) are vital to growth, development, metabolism,
and energy expenditure, but are especially important in the early
development of vertebrates.15 THs homeostasis
is sensitive to many environmental toxicants, and can be affected
by thyroid gland development, THs synthesis and transportation, liver
elimination, and hypothalamus-pituitary feedback regulation.16 Transthyretin (TTR), deiodinases, and thyroid
receptors (TRs) have been implicated in thyroid endocrine disruption.15,17 The bioactive form of TH is T3, which interacts with TRs at tissue-specific
effects.18,19 The predominant thyroid isoform, TRβ,
has a key role in the regulation of target gene transcription.20 Its interaction with thyroid endocrine disrupting
chemicals leads to abnormal TH levels and activity.21,22 Thyroid endocrine disruptions can be caused by NBFRs, such as bis(2-ethylhexyl)
tetrabromophthalate (TBPH),19 decabromodiphenyl
ethane (DBDPE),23,24 and pentabromoethylbenzene (PBEB).25 Given that the structure of BTBPE is similar
to that of PBDEs and TH,9 its potential
thyroid endocrine disruptions are well worth exploring. Limited toxicological
studies have shown that BTBPE exposure may impair thyroid function.
Chicken eggs exposed to BTBPE have decreased type III iodothyronine
5′-deiodinase (Dio3) gene transcription,26 whereas embryonic exposure to BTBPE in the American
kestrel (Falco sparverius) inhibits type 2 deiodinase
(Dio2) activity.27 One
study showed a positive correlation between the BTBPE found in dust
and human T3 levels suggesting thyroid endocrine disruption.28 The thyroid-disrupting effects of BTBPE are
not well-researched nor are the related mechanisms. Given its
increased use and potential risk to wildlife and humans,
exploring BTBPE and its effects on the thyroid endocrine system and
human and environmental health is warranted. We evaluated the thyroid-disrupting
effects of BTBPE as follows: (1) Molecular docking in silico identified
affinity and interactions between BTBPE and TRs; (2) In vitro recombinant
yeast two-hybrid and T-Screen assays were used for rapid screening
of thyroid-disrupting potentials; (3) BTBPE was tested for thyroid-disrupting
activity using zebrafish larvae; and (4) The locomotion of zebrafish
larvae was examined to assess developmental neurotoxicity. This is
the first in silico and in vitro evidence of the interaction between
TRβ and BTBPE and the subsequent thyroid-disrupting effects.
These results facilitate further environmental risk assessment of
BTBPE.

sections.title: Materials and Methods
sections.text:
We used BTBPE (CAS no. 37853-59-1;
99%) from Toronto Research Chemicals (Toronto, Canada), 3,3′,5-Triiodo-l-thyronine (T3) (CAS no. 6893-02-3, >98%) from Tokyo Chemical
Industry Co., Ltd. (Tokyo, Japan), 13C-PCB208 (CAS no.
234432-92-9; ≥98%), an internal standard, from Cambridge Isotope
Laboratories (Andover, U.S.A.), methanesulfonate (MS-222, CAS: 886-86-2)
and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) (>99.9%) from Sigma-Aldrich (St.
Louis,
MO, U.S.A.). All other chemical reagents were analytical or chromatography
grade. We used molecular docking to explore the interaction between BTBPE
and zebrafish TRs (TRα, TRβ) as detailed in previous studies.29 The zebrafish thyroid hormone receptor protein
structure was predicted using homology modeling through the Build
Homology model procedure in Discovery Studio 2016 software (Accelrys
Software Inc., U.S.A.). We chose the conformation with the lowest
CDOCKER energy for the binding site. It was identified to calculate
the binding energy, which was utilized to evaluate zebrafish TR affinity
for BTBPE and T3 (the positive control). Details of the procedure
are provided in Supporting Information (SI Text S1). The recombinant
yeast two-hybrid assay that rapidly screens for TR disruption potential
was conducted following a previously described method.22 Yeast cells were grown in SD/-Leu/-Trp medium
at 30 °C for 24 h. For the agonistic activity assay, the cells
were exposed to BTBPE (0, 125, 250, 500, 1000 nmol/L) for 2.5 h and
T3 (500 nmol/L) was coexposed with BTBPE to measure antagonistic activity.
Following lysis with chloroform, the reaction was started by adding o-nitrophenyl-β-d-galactopyranoside, after
1 h, it was stopped by adding sodium carbonate. The β-galactosidase
activity (U) was quantified at a 420 nm wavelength (OD420) (TECAN GENios A-5002, Salzburg, Austria). All assays were conducted
three times using three samples for each assay. The T-Screen assay
for rapid screening of thyroid endocrine disruption
uses a rat pituitary tumor cell line (GH3). It works through a specific,
high-affinity thyroid receptor (TR) pathway, stimulating the synthesis
and secretion of growth hormone (GH) to facilitate cell proliferation.30 We obtained GH3 cells from the National Experimental
Cell Resource Sharing Platform (Beijing, China). Cells were maintained
at 37 °C and 5% CO2 exposure using Ham’s F-12K
(Kaighn’s) medium supplemented with 2.5% fetal bovine serum
(FBS; provided by Gibco, LifeTechnologies, Carlsbad, CA, U.S.A.),
15% horse serum, and 1% penicillin/streptomycin. At 24 h, we replaced
this medium with a serum-free medium to starve the cells for 24 h
before BTBPE exposure (0, 1.5, 15, 150, 1000, 1500 nmol/L) for 96
h. Antagonistic activity was measured using T3 (1, 10, 25 nmol/L)
for coexposure with BTBPE. Cell viability was determined by observing
the colorimetric transformation of WST-8 into formazan using the Cell
Counting Kit-8 (Servicebio, Wuhan, China) with the formazan wavelength
of 490 ± (OD490). All assays were repeated three times,
with each exposure including a blank and a solvent control (0.1% v/v
DMSO). The mature zebrafish (wild-type, AB strain) were cultured and embryonic
exposure was conducted according to a previously documented method.23 We randomly selected 400 fertilized embryos
(2 h post fertilization, hpf) and placed them in a glass beaker with
200 mL of BTBPE solution (0, 1, 3, 10 μg/L). We administered
0.1% (v/v) DMSO to the control and treatment groups. The exposure
time for four replicates was 14 days. The exposure solution was refreshed
daily and temperature was maintained at 28 ± 0.5 °C, following
a 14/10 h light/dark cycle. Twice daily, zebrafish larvae were nourished
with egg yolk and cultured Artemia. Developmental
indices, including hatching, survival, heart rate, and body length,
were recorded. At 14 days post fertilization (dpf), we collected and
anesthetized larvae using 0.03% MS-222 (300 mg/L), then froze them
in liquid nitrogen with subsequent preservation at −80 °C
for future analysis. These procedures followed the Guidelines for
the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals of the Institute of Hydrobiology,
Chinese Academy of Sciences. BTBPE concentrations in the exposure
solutions and larvae (14 dpf, n = 4 replicates)
were measured following a previously described method.31 We used an Agilent 7890B-7000c gas chromatography–mass
spectrometry (GC/MS) to quantify BTBPE. We used 13C-PCB
208 as the internal standard. The limit of detection (LOD) (defined
as 3-fold the signal/noise ratio) and the limit of quantification
(LOQ) were 3 μg/L and 10 μg/L, respectively. The recovery
rate of BTBPE was 97.5 ± 6.9% in exposure solution, and 102.9
± 7.9% in larvae, respectively. The sample pretreatment, analysis,
quality assurance, and quality control (QA/QC) are available in the SI (Text S2). Extraction of whole-body larval TH (14 dpf, 200
larvae per sample, n = 4 replicates) was based on
a previous method.23 Details are provided
in SI (Text S3). T4, T3, CRH, and TSH were
measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (T4, T3: Cloud-Clone
Corp, Wuhan, China; CRH, TSH: Keygentec, Nanjing, China) according
to the manufacturer’s instructions. The detection limits for
T4, T3, CRH, and TSH were 1.29 ng/mL, 50.5 pg/mL, 0.5 ng/mL, and 0.2
mU/L, respectively, as indicated by the manufacturer. The intra-assay
variations and the interassay variations reported by the manufacturer
are below 10% and 12% for all hormones, respectively. The hormone
concentrations were normalized against protein content using a commercial
kit utilizing the Bradford method (Keygentec, Nanjing, China). We measured the
transcription of select genes related to thyroid hormone synthesis,
transport, regulation, and metabolism in the HPT axis of zebrafish
larvae. We used RNAiso Plus (TaKaRa Bio Inc., Japan) to extract total
RNA from homogenized whole larvae fish (14 dpf; 100 larvae; n = 4 replicates). Following previously described protocols,
we extracted and purified total RNA, synthesized first-strand cDNA,
and conducted quantitative real-time PCRs.23 We obtained the primer sequences of the target genes from a previous
study (SI Table S1).23 Real-time PCR results were determined by threshold cycle
(Ct) number and gene transcription levels
were normalized using the 2–ΔΔCt method with β-actin used
as a housekeeping gene. We monitored
spontaneous locomotion and phototaxis. Embryos (22–25 hpf)
were selected and video-recorded for 1 min using a CCD camera (Nikon,
Japan) to count the number of tail swings per embryo as a measure
of spontaneous movement.32 We used 60 embryos
in each treatment group from four replicates for data analysis. We conducted phototaxis assays (swimming from dark to light areas)
at 5 dpf using a previously described method.33 An opaque black acrylic box (10.5 × 3 × 4 cm3 in length × width × height) was separated into chamber
A and chamber B with a sliding partition in the middle. We placed
24 randomly selected larvae per replicate (n = 4
replicates) in chamber B with the partition closed for 5 min under
darkness. After removing the partition, the chamber B remained in
the dark and the chamber A were exposed to 200 lx of ambient light.
After 1 min, we reclosed the partition, subsequently counted zebrafish
in chamber A and B. The chamber structure is provided in SI (Figure S1). We monitored 14 dpf larvae
for the locomotion behavior assay using
the Zebralab Video-Track system (ViewPoint Life Sciences Inc., Montreal,
Canada), following a previous method.32 Normal zebrafish larvae were moved into a 24-well plate (one larvae/well).
Following 5 min of adaptation, we measured larval locomotion in 5
min dark-5 min light-5 min dark cycles and monitored swimming speed
using 48 larvae per treatment from four replicates. The movement frequency
and distance were recorded every 30 s. All locomotion behavior experiments
were conducted at 28 °C. All values are
expressed as mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM). Data were
verified for normality using Shapiro–Wilk’s test and
for homogeneity of variance using Levene’s test. One-way analysis
of variance (ANOVA) with least significant difference (LSD) posthoc
assessed statistical significance. We used SPSS software v22.0 (IBM,
U.S.A.) for statistical analysis and GraphPad Prism 8.0 (Avenida,
CA, U.S.A.) software to generate figures. A p-value
less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

Statistical
Analyses
sections.text:
All values are
expressed as mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM). Data were
verified for normality using Shapiro–Wilk’s test and
for homogeneity of variance using Levene’s test. One-way analysis
of variance (ANOVA) with least significant difference (LSD) posthoc

sections.title: Results
sections.text:
We used a Ramachandran plot to evaluate the
predicted models (SI Figure S2). The interaction
energies of T3
with TRα and TRβ were −60.16 and −58.2282
kcal/mol, respectively. Furthermore, T3 and TRα hydrogen bonds
were formed with residues GLY315, ARG265, MET296, and HIS418 and between
T3 and TRβ with residues ARG256 and THR312 (Figure S3). Optimal BTBPE conformations with TRα and
TRβ are shown in Figures 1A and 1B. The docking interaction energies
for BTBPE with TRα and TRβ are −36.4005 and −30.6469
kcal/mol, respectively. Figure 1C shows π–π and π-alkyl bonds formed
between BTBPE and TRα with residues HIS193 and ILE390, respectively.
BTBPE interactions with TRβ include π-anion at ASP324
and π-alkyl and alkyl at HIS195, TRP196, and VAL327, respectively
(Figure 1D). Molecular docking
of BTBPE. 3D conformation of BTBPE with (A) TRα
and (B) TRβ; 2D diagram of interaction between BTBPE and (C)
TRα and (D) TRβ. Contact residues are labeled by type
and number in 2-D diagrams. Residue color and dotted lines indicate
interaction types. The exposure
concentrations did not affect cell viability. Concentration-dependent
T3 treatments (15.6, 31.3, 62.5, 125.0, 250.0, 500.0 nmol/L) induced
β-galactosidase activity (SI Figure S4). Exposure to BTBPE induced β-galactosidase activity in the
agonistic activity assay, with induction rates increasing of 1.17%
and 4.47% in the 500 and 1000 nmol/L treatment groups, respectively
(Figure 2A). In the
antagonistic activity assay, inhibition rates in the 250, 500, 1000
nmol/L treatment groups were increased by 10.44%, 8.35%, and 36.11%,
respectively (Figure 2B). (A) Induction and (B) inhibition rates after BTBPE exposure The
antagonistic activity of BTBPE is represented as the percent inhibition
rate relative to the maximum induced by 500 nmol/L T3 with *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01 indicating significance.
The values of the control group were considered as 0. Data are expressed
as the mean ± SEM of triplicate assays. The exposure concentrations
did not affect cell viability. Treatment with T3 increased GH3 proliferation
in a concentration-dependent manner, with increases of 206.3% and
198.4%, in the 0.5 and 1 nmol/L treatment groups, respectively (Figure 3A). Exposure to BTBPE
also increased GH3 cell proliferation (Figure 3B) by 138%, 135%, 119%, and 120% in the 15,
150, 1000, 1500 nmol/L treatment groups, respectively. When GH3 cells
were coexposed to BTBPE (1500 nmol/L) in the presence of T3 (1, 10,
25 nmol/L), the T3-induced proliferation of GH3 cells was inhibited
(Figure 3C). Induced cell
proliferation in the T-Screening assays. The GH3 cells
were exposed to (A) T3, (B) BTBPE and (C) T3 with 1500 nmol/L BTBPE.
The asterisks denote significant differences in treatment groups compared
with the solvent control: *p < 0.05 and **p < 0.01. The cell proliferation count was determined
by the absorbance value at 490 nm wavelength. All data are expressed
as mean ± SEM values of triplicate assays. In the 1, 3, and 10 μg/L treatment
groups, the quantified average concentrations of BTBPE were 1.21 ±
0.04, 4.96 ± 0.57, and 8.44 ± 0.16 μg/L, respectively,
upon renewal of exposure solution. After 24 h exposure, the measured
average concentrations of BTBPE were 0.89 ± 0.02, 2.77 ±
0.47, and 3.77 ± 0.38 μg/L. In the 1, 3, and 10 μg/L
treatment groups, BTBPE increased in a concentration-dependent manner,
with average concentrations of 2.61 ± 1.04, 3.16 ± 0.54,
and 5.71 ± 2.96 μg/g d.w. (dry weight) in zebrafish, respectively.
The control group BTBPE concentrations were lower than the detection
limit in both the exposure solution and zebrafish larvae. The hatching
rates did not change at 48, 60, and 72 hpf. Survival and malformation
rates did not change at 120 hpf and body length did not change at
14 dpf. However, all BTBPE treatment groups showed reduced embryonic
heart rates at 36 hpf (Table S2, Figure S5). Exposure to BTBPE reduced T4 concentrations in the 1, 3, and 10
μg/L treatment groups (Figure 4A). The T3 concentration did not remarkably change
(Figure 4B). All treatment
groups showed increases in CRH levels (Figure 4C). Concentration of TSH increased in 3 μg/L
groups (Figure 4D). Effects
of BTBPE on T4 (A), T3 (B), CRH (C), and TSH (D) at 14
dpf. The asterisks indicate significant differences in treatment groups
compared with the solvent control: *p < 0.05 and
**p < 0.01. All data are expressed as mean ±
SEM values from four replicates of each group. In all BTBPE
treatment groups, tg transcription upregulated in
all treatment groups, whereas tpo transcription upregulated
in the 3 and 10 μg/L treatment groups. TH transporter gene,
the transcription of ttr was significantly decreased
in the 10 μg/L treatment group (Table 1). The dio1 gene expression

increase in the 3 and 10 μg/L treatment groups (Table 1). Transcription of
selected genes
in zebrafish larvae exposed to BTBPE for 14 days. All data are expressed
as mean ± SEM values from four replicates of each group. The
asterisks indicate significant differences in treatment groups compared
with the solvent control. p < 0.05 and. p < 0.01. The average
spontaneous movement of embryos, as measured by the number of bends
per minute, was 7.41 in the control group. The 1, 3, and 10 μg/L
BTBPE treatment groups showed a decrease of 49.6%, 30.5%, and 40.0%

exposure groups (Figure 5B). During the light/dark stimulation period, the locomotion of 14
dpf larvae was observed (Figure 5C). The average speed during light and dark stimulation
was decreased in the 1, 3, and 10 μg/L treatment groups (Figure 5D and Figure 5E). Swimming distance was also
reduced in the 1, 3, and 10 μg/L treatment groups (Figure 5F). Effects of BTBPE on locomotor
behavior in zebrafish. (A) Spontaneous

sections.title:
Molecular Docking with
Zebrafish TR
sections.text:
We used a Ramachandran plot to evaluate the
predicted models (SI Figure S2). The interaction
energies of T3
with TRα and TRβ were −60.16 and −58.2282
kcal/mol, respectively. Furthermore, T3 and TRα hydrogen bonds
were formed with residues GLY315, ARG265, MET296, and HIS418 and between
T3 and TRβ with residues ARG256 and THR312 (Figure S3). Optimal BTBPE conformations with TRα and
TRβ are shown in Figures 1A and 1B. The docking interaction energies
for BTBPE with TRα and TRβ are −36.4005 and −30.6469
kcal/mol, respectively. Figure 1C shows π–π and π-alkyl bonds formed
between BTBPE and TRα with residues HIS193 and ILE390, respectively.
BTBPE interactions with TRβ include π-anion at ASP324
and π-alkyl and alkyl at HIS195, TRP196, and VAL327, respectively
(Figure 1D). Molecular docking
of BTBPE. 3D conformation of BTBPE with (A) TRα
and (B) TRβ; 2D diagram of interaction between BTBPE and (C)
TRα and (D) TRβ. Contact residues are labeled by type
and number in 2-D diagrams. Residue color and dotted lines indicate
interaction types.

sections.title:
Yeast
Two-Hybrid Assay
sections.text:
The exposure
concentrations did not affect cell viability. Concentration-dependent

agonistic activity assay, with induction rates increasing of 1.17%
and 4.47% in the 500 and 1000 nmol/L treatment groups, respectively
(Figure 2A). In the
antagonistic activity assay, inhibition rates in the 250, 500, 1000
nmol/L treatment groups were increased by 10.44%, 8.35%, and 36.11%,
respectively (Figure 2B). (A) Induction and (B) inhibition rates after BTBPE exposure The
antagonistic activity of BTBPE is represented as the percent inhibition
rate relative to the maximum induced by 500 nmol/L T3 with *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01 indicating significance.
The values of the control group were considered as 0. Data are expressed
as the mean ± SEM of triplicate assays.

sections.title: T-Screen
sections.text:

did not affect cell viability. Treatment with T3 increased GH3 proliferation

198.4%, in the 0.5 and 1 nmol/L treatment groups, respectively (Figure 3A). Exposure to BTBPE

150, 1000, 1500 nmol/L treatment groups, respectively. When GH3 cells

25 nmol/L), the T3-induced proliferation of GH3 cells was inhibited
(Figure 3C). Induced cell

were exposed to (A) T3, (B) BTBPE and (C) T3 with 1500 nmol/L BTBPE.
The asterisks denote significant differences in treatment groups compared
with the solvent control: *p < 0.05 and **p < 0.01. The cell proliferation count was determined
by the absorbance value at 490 nm wavelength. All data are expressed
as mean ± SEM values of triplicate assays.

upon renewal of exposure solution. After 24 h exposure, the measured

sections.title: Development Toxicities
sections.text:
The hatching
rates did not change at 48, 60, and 72 hpf. Survival and malformation
rates did not change at 120 hpf and body length did not change at
14 dpf. However, all BTBPE treatment groups showed reduced embryonic
heart rates at 36 hpf (Table S2, Figure S5).

In all BTBPE

sections.title: Locomotor Activity
sections.text:
The average
spontaneous movement of embryos, as measured by the number of bends
per minute, was 7.41 in the control group. The 1, 3, and 10 μg/L
BTBPE treatment groups showed a decrease of 49.6%, 30.5%, and 40.0%
in movement, respectively (Figure 5A). Larval phototaxis was reduced in the 3 and 10 μg/L
exposure groups (Figure 5B). During the light/dark stimulation period, the locomotion of 14
dpf larvae was observed (Figure 5C). The average speed during light and dark stimulation
was decreased in the 1, 3, and 10 μg/L treatment groups (Figure 5D and Figure 5E). Swimming distance was also
reduced in the 1, 3, and 10 μg/L treatment groups (Figure 5F). Effects of BTBPE on locomotor

sections.title: Discussion
sections.text:
Molecular docking explores
the interaction between xenobiotics
and target receptors, determines their toxicological mode of action,29 and was a critical step in determining the affinity
of BTBPE for TRs in this study. BTBPE docked with TR isoforms (i.e.,
TRα and TRβ) by fitting into the active pocket and engaging
in interactions such as π–π stacking, π-anion,
π-alkyl, and alkyl with distinct amino acids. Other BFRs, e.g.,
tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) has been proved to dock with TR-LBD
(ligand binding domain) through π-alkyl, alkyl interactions.34 Having evidence that BTBPE can bind with zebrafish
TRαβ LBD such as T3 suggested that BTBPE was a potential
TR agonist. The in vitro rapid screening assay revealed thyroid
endocrine potential
via TR signaling pathway. In the recombinant TRβ two-hybrid
yeast assay, increased β-galactosidase activity indicated that
BTBPE activates the TR signaling-mediated pathway toward agonistic
activities. The effects of thyroid disruptors, e.g., TBBPA35 and hydroxylated polybrominated biphenyls (OH-PBBs),36 have been demonstrated. We further evaluated
the antagonistic activity of BTBPE when coincubated with T3. Co-administration
of BTBPE with T3 shows a marked inhibition of β-galactosidase
activity relative to T3 treatment, indicating BTBPE disruption of
the thyroid endocrine system through the TR regulatory system. Futhermore,
exposure to BTBPE increased GH3 cell proliferation in the T-Screen
assay, whereas it was inhibited when coexposed with T3, indicating
its agonist potential via TR pathway.37 GH3 cells possess many enzymes, such as TRs, TSH, and deiodinase,
and its proliferation sensitive to T3 level.38,39 Hence, GH3 cell proliferation rate may better predict agonistic/antagonistic
activity of chemicals that have thyroid endocrine potential. The T-Screen
test effectively anticipates the impact of specific chemicals that
disrupt thyroid hormones, including BFRs, polychlorinated biphenyls
(PCBs), and pentachlorophenol, by measuring cell proliferation rate.40,41 We found that both yeast and T-Screening assays are useful for predicting
thyroid endocrine disruption potential via TR-mediated signaling for
BTBPE. Decreased T4 was observed in BTBPE exposure groups, but
not in
the T3. Previous studies have indicated that circulating T3 does not
change with decreased T4 level after exposure to thyroid endocrine-disrupting
chemicals, such as penta-BDEs mixture (DE-71), 2,2′,4,4’5-pentain
polybrominated diphenyl ethers (BDE-99), and decabromodiphenyl ether
(BDE-209),42−44 suggesting that decreased T4 does not limit the T3
supply to the plasma pool, and such regulation mechanism is crucial
for maintaining homeostasis. Studies have shown that the impact of
thyroid endocrine-disrupting activity on T3 levels is unremarkable
compared to its effects on T4 levels in rodents and fish.45,46 This suggests that T4 response is more sensitive than T3 response
to thyroid chemicals stimulation. Increased T4 levels were reported
in bromoacetamide and DE-7147 and NBFRs.
Zebrafish larvae exposure to DBDPE,23 or
3,3′,5,5′-Tetrabromobiphenyl (BB80) for 14 days significantly
increased T4 level.48 The divergence in
reported T4 change may depend on chemical characteristics exposure
time, model species, and exposure route or concentrations. Exposing
zebrafish larvae to DE-71 for 14 days reduces T4, whereas long-term
exposure of DE-71 to adult zebrafish increases T4.42,47 We found that BTBPE is similar to penta-BDE in how it disrupts thyroid
hormones levels. Concentrations of TSH and CRH were increased
via a negative feedback
mechanism regulating the HPT axis, where the secretion of TSH by the
pituitary gland controls the synthesis and release of T4 by the thyroid
follicles. This mechanism allows for response-regulated change in
T4 level. CRH promotes TSH secretion in nonmammalian vertebrates like
amphibians and fish,49 suggesting its potential
role as a universal controller of the thyroidal axis. In this scenario,
elevated CRH and TSH levels are crucial parts of a negative feedback
mechanism that compensates for reduced TH. Hence, we evaluated the
gene transcription profiles associated with the HPT axis, and observed
increased transcription of tg and tpo genes with BTBPE treatment. The transcription of tg and tpo are involved in TH synthesis.50 Zebrafish larvae exposed to various chemical
contaminants (such as BDE-209, DE-71, benzophenone) shown increased
transcription of these genes,accompanied by decreased T4 levels.38,42,44 Other studies have shown decreased tg and tpo gene transcription and increased
T4 levels after exposure to pentabromoethylbenzene.25 Thus, the upregulation of these gene transcription in response
to reduced T4 levels may be compensatory. The ttr gene transcription only decreased in the highest BTBPE exposure
group. The transport of TH involves ttr as does the
regulation of TH supply to different target tissues in fish.51 Derivatives and metabolites of PCBs and phenol
compounds that share a structure similar to THs may influence circulating
TH levels in vertebrates by competing for binding sites on transport
proteins.52 When exposure to BTBPE decreases ttr gene transcription, it reduces the TTR available for
binding to TH. As a result, the unbound T4 is more susceptible to
liver catabolism, increased elimination, and reduced TH circulation.
Similarly, exposure to DE-71 reduced ttr transcription
meanwhile decreasing T4 level.44 We observed
a concentration-dependent upregulation of the ugt1ab gene. Its enzyme activity affects TH metabolism by modifying T4
level, via glucuronidation, for excretion through bile.53 It can decrease TH levels through T4 glucuronidation
in both animal and in vitro models.38 The
BTBPE-triggered increase in ugt1ab transcription
may amplify thyroid hormone elimination, ultimately leading to reduced
TH levels in zebrafish larvae. Deiodinase genes transcription
was decreased in dio2, dio3a, and dio3b, but unchanged
in dio1. Deiodinases regulate TH levels in plasma
and peripheral tissue, and deiodinase gene transcription is influenced
by TH levels in turn.49 For example, higher
levels of TH reduce dio2 transcription and lower
levels increase it.54 In addition, higher
levels of TH increase dio3 transcription whereas
lower levels and normal physiological conditions decrease it. However,
such rules are not entirely consistent with the disruptions caused
by toxicants. For example, in rats exposed to hexachlorobenzene, dio1 increased but circulating T4 and dio2 transcription decreased.55 Walleye (Sander vitreus) treated with endocrine-disrupting chemicals
have elevated dio2 transcription, T3, and
T4 levels, whereas the hepatic mRNA of dio1 and dio3 remained unchanged.56 In
rats given PCB153, T4 dropped and dio2 gene transcription
was suppressed but there was no discernible effect on the dio1 or dio3 genes.57 Other studies found that zebrafish larvae exposed to DBDPE
for 14 days had increased T4 and T3 levels, reduced dio1, and elevated dio2, dio3a, and dio3b gene transcription.23 Gene
transcription of deiodinases occurs in a cell or tissue type-specific
manner suggesting that there is a divergent molecular transcript response
to the thyroid endocrine disruption chemicals. This is more complex
than a secondary reaction to changed TH levels.54,58 We have no evidence if toxicants alter deiodinase activity in TH-targeted
tissues or if deiodinase activity is the primary or secondary result
of toxicant exposure.54 Zebrafish
locomotion is an established end point for evaluating
the effect of environmental pollutants on developmental neurotoxicity.32 Our study indicated that BTBPE causes developmental
neurotoxicity in that it suppresses spontaneous movement, swimming
activity, and visual acuity. This is consistent with another study
indicating that PBDEs exposure can reduce movement and impairs visual
acuity.59 Because TH plays a vital role
in brain development, any disruptions in TH balance may impair neurological
development.60 PBDEs inhibit nervous system
development by altering TH levels.61 Previous
studies have shown that exposure to PBDEs impairs locomotion in embryonic
and larval zebrafish.62 Other studies have
suggested that thyroid hormone signaling participates in early eye
development and regulation of photoreceptor patterns.16,59,63 Hence, thyroid signaling disturbances
caused by BTBPE may disrupt retinal development and neural function.

sections.title: Conclusions
sections.text:
This study first determined
that exposure
to BTBPE leads to thyroid
dysfunction and in neurotoxicity in developing fish. For better understanding
of the adverse health impacts and assessing environmental risks of
BTBPE, future research should investigate the BTBPE toxicokinetics
and tissue distribution in organisms, how BTBPE acts on the thyroid
system, and if exposure to environmentally relevant BTBPE concentrations
impacts organism health. In addition, given the critical function
of thyroid hormones in the early development of the central nervous
system, there is also a need to investigate the effects of BTBPE on
neurons.

full_text:
## Introduction
The manufacture and use
of primary legacy brominated flame retardants
(BFRs), e.g., polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs), have been limited
worldwide and novel brominated flame retardants (NBFRs) have replaced
them. Increased use of 1,2-bis (2,4,6-tribromophenoxy) ethane (BTBPE),
a typical NBFR, has created widespread environmental contamination.1,2 It has been detected in air,3 dust,4 soils,5 sediments,6 sludge, and surface water.7 Due to their highly hydrophobicity, BTBPE is seldom analyzed
in surface water and up to 5.22 ng/L has been reported.8 However, like PBDEs, BTBPE shows environmental
persistence and potential for bioaccumulation.1,9 It
is present in mud carp (Cirrhinus molitorella) (518
± 277 ng/g l.w.), crucian carp (Carassius auratus) (332 ± 315 ng/g l.w.),10 and shark
livers (up to 16.7 ng/g l.w.).11 BTBPE
has been shown in the food web of the South China Sea tropics.12 It has been detected in breast milk13 and human serum.14 The widespread presence of BTBPE indicates the need for the study
of its environmental effects and potential toxicity. Thyroid
hormones (THs) are vital to growth, development, metabolism,
and energy expenditure, but are especially important in the early
development of vertebrates.15 THs homeostasis
is sensitive to many environmental toxicants, and can be affected
by thyroid gland development, THs synthesis and transportation, liver
elimination, and hypothalamus-pituitary feedback regulation.16 Transthyretin (TTR), deiodinases, and thyroid
receptors (TRs) have been implicated in thyroid endocrine disruption.15,17 The bioactive form of TH is T3, which interacts with TRs at tissue-specific
effects.18,19 The predominant thyroid isoform, TRβ,
has a key role in the regulation of target gene transcription.20 Its interaction with thyroid endocrine disrupting
chemicals leads to abnormal TH levels and activity.21,22 Thyroid endocrine disruptions can be caused by NBFRs, such as bis(2-ethylhexyl)
tetrabromophthalate (TBPH),19 decabromodiphenyl
ethane (DBDPE),23,24 and pentabromoethylbenzene (PBEB).25 Given that the structure of BTBPE is similar
to that of PBDEs and TH,9 its potential
thyroid endocrine disruptions are well worth exploring. Limited toxicological
studies have shown that BTBPE exposure may impair thyroid function.
Chicken eggs exposed to BTBPE have decreased type III iodothyronine
5′-deiodinase (Dio3) gene transcription,26 whereas embryonic exposure to BTBPE in the American
kestrel (Falco sparverius) inhibits type 2 deiodinase
(Dio2) activity.27 One
study showed a positive correlation between the BTBPE found in dust
and human T3 levels suggesting thyroid endocrine disruption.28 The thyroid-disrupting effects of BTBPE are
not well-researched nor are the related mechanisms. Given its
increased use and potential risk to wildlife and humans,
exploring BTBPE and its effects on the thyroid endocrine system and
human and environmental health is warranted. We evaluated the thyroid-disrupting
effects of BTBPE as follows: (1) Molecular docking in silico identified
affinity and interactions between BTBPE and TRs; (2) In vitro recombinant
yeast two-hybrid and T-Screen assays were used for rapid screening
of thyroid-disrupting potentials; (3) BTBPE was tested for thyroid-disrupting
activity using zebrafish larvae; and (4) The locomotion of zebrafish
larvae was examined to assess developmental neurotoxicity. This is
the first in silico and in vitro evidence of the interaction between
TRβ and BTBPE and the subsequent thyroid-disrupting effects.
These results facilitate further environmental risk assessment of
BTBPE.

## Materials and Methods
We used BTBPE (CAS no. 37853-59-1;
99%) from Toronto Research Chemicals (Toronto, Canada), 3,3′,5-Triiodo-l-thyronine (T3) (CAS no. 6893-02-3, >98%) from Tokyo Chemical
Industry Co., Ltd. (Tokyo, Japan), 13C-PCB208 (CAS no.
234432-92-9; ≥98%), an internal standard, from Cambridge Isotope
Laboratories (Andover, U.S.A.), methanesulfonate (MS-222, CAS: 886-86-2)
and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) (>99.9%) from Sigma-Aldrich (St.
Louis,
MO, U.S.A.). All other chemical reagents were analytical or chromatography
grade. We used molecular docking to explore the interaction between BTBPE
and zebrafish TRs (TRα, TRβ) as detailed in previous studies.29 The zebrafish thyroid hormone receptor protein
structure was predicted using homology modeling through the Build
Homology model procedure in Discovery Studio 2016 software (Accelrys
Software Inc., U.S.A.). We chose the conformation with the lowest
CDOCKER energy for the binding site. It was identified to calculate
the binding energy, which was utilized to evaluate zebrafish TR affinity
for BTBPE and T3 (the positive control). Details of the procedure
are provided in Supporting Information (SI Text S1). The recombinant
yeast two-hybrid assay that rapidly screens for TR disruption potential
was conducted following a previously described method.22 Yeast cells were grown in SD/-Leu/-Trp medium
at 30 °C for 24 h. For the agonistic activity assay, the cells
were exposed to BTBPE (0, 125, 250, 500, 1000 nmol/L) for 2.5 h and
T3 (500 nmol/L) was coexposed with BTBPE to measure antagonistic activity.
Following lysis with chloroform, the reaction was started by adding o-nitrophenyl-β-d-galactopyranoside, after
1 h, it was stopped by adding sodium carbonate. The β-galactosidase
activity (U) was quantified at a 420 nm wavelength (OD420) (TECAN GENios A-5002, Salzburg, Austria). All assays were conducted
three times using three samples for each assay. The T-Screen assay
for rapid screening of thyroid endocrine disruption
uses a rat pituitary tumor cell line (GH3). It works through a specific,
high-affinity thyroid receptor (TR) pathway, stimulating the synthesis
and secretion of growth hormone (GH) to facilitate cell proliferation.30 We obtained GH3 cells from the National Experimental
Cell Resource Sharing Platform (Beijing, China). Cells were maintained
at 37 °C and 5% CO2 exposure using Ham’s F-12K
(Kaighn’s) medium supplemented with 2.5% fetal bovine serum
(FBS; provided by Gibco, LifeTechnologies, Carlsbad, CA, U.S.A.),
15% horse serum, and 1% penicillin/streptomycin. At 24 h, we replaced
this medium with a serum-free medium to starve the cells for 24 h
before BTBPE exposure (0, 1.5, 15, 150, 1000, 1500 nmol/L) for 96
h. Antagonistic activity was measured using T3 (1, 10, 25 nmol/L)

## Reagents
We used BTBPE (CAS no. 37853-59-1;
99%) from Toronto Research Chemicals (Toronto, Canada), 3,3′,5-Triiodo-l-thyronine (T3) (CAS no. 6893-02-3, >98%) from Tokyo Chemical
Industry Co., Ltd. (Tokyo, Japan), 13C-PCB208 (CAS no.
234432-92-9; ≥98%), an internal standard, from Cambridge Isotope
Laboratories (Andover, U.S.A.), methanesulfonate (MS-222, CAS: 886-86-2)
and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) (>99.9%) from Sigma-Aldrich (St.
Louis,
MO, U.S.A.). All other chemical reagents were analytical or chromatography
grade.

## Homology Modeling and Molecular Docking Analysis
We used molecular docking to explore the interaction between BTBPE
and zebrafish TRs (TRα, TRβ) as detailed in previous studies.29 The zebrafish thyroid hormone receptor protein
structure was predicted using homology modeling through the Build
Homology model procedure in Discovery Studio 2016 software (Accelrys
Software Inc., U.S.A.). We chose the conformation with the lowest
CDOCKER energy for the binding site. It was identified to calculate
the binding energy, which was utilized to evaluate zebrafish TR affinity
for BTBPE and T3 (the positive control). Details of the procedure
are provided in Supporting Information (SI Text S1).

## Yeast Two-Hybrid Assay
The recombinant
yeast two-hybrid assay that rapidly screens for TR disruption potential
was conducted following a previously described method.22 Yeast cells were grown in SD/-Leu/-Trp medium
at 30 °C for 24 h. For the agonistic activity assay, the cells
were exposed to BTBPE (0, 125, 250, 500, 1000 nmol/L) for 2.5 h and
T3 (500 nmol/L) was coexposed with BTBPE to measure antagonistic activity.
Following lysis with chloroform, the reaction was started by adding o-nitrophenyl-β-d-galactopyranoside, after
1 h, it was stopped by adding sodium carbonate. The β-galactosidase
activity (U) was quantified at a 420 nm wavelength (OD420) (TECAN GENios A-5002, Salzburg, Austria). All assays were conducted
three times using three samples for each assay.

## GH3 Cell Culture and T-Screen Assay
The T-Screen assay
for rapid screening of thyroid endocrine disruption
uses a rat pituitary tumor cell line (GH3). It works through a specific,
high-affinity thyroid receptor (TR) pathway, stimulating the synthesis
and secretion of growth hormone (GH) to facilitate cell proliferation.30 We obtained GH3 cells from the National Experimental
Cell Resource Sharing Platform (Beijing, China). Cells were maintained
at 37 °C and 5% CO2 exposure using Ham’s F-12K
(Kaighn’s) medium supplemented with 2.5% fetal bovine serum
(FBS; provided by Gibco, LifeTechnologies, Carlsbad, CA, U.S.A.),
15% horse serum, and 1% penicillin/streptomycin. At 24 h, we replaced
this medium with a serum-free medium to starve the cells for 24 h
before BTBPE exposure (0, 1.5, 15, 150, 1000, 1500 nmol/L) for 96
h. Antagonistic activity was measured using T3 (1, 10, 25 nmol/L)
for coexposure with BTBPE. Cell viability was determined by observing
the colorimetric transformation of WST-8 into formazan using the Cell
Counting Kit-8 (Servicebio, Wuhan, China) with the formazan wavelength
of 490 ± (OD490). All assays were repeated three times,
with each exposure including a blank and a solvent control (0.1% v/v
DMSO).

## Quantification of BTBPE
in Exposure Solution
and Zebrafish Larvae
BTBPE concentrations in the exposure
solutions and larvae (14 dpf, n = 4 replicates)
were measured following a previously described method.31 We used an Agilent 7890B-7000c gas chromatography–mass
spectrometry (GC/MS) to quantify BTBPE. We used 13C-PCB
208 as the internal standard. The limit of detection (LOD) (defined
as 3-fold the signal/noise ratio) and the limit of quantification
(LOQ) were 3 μg/L and 10 μg/L, respectively. The recovery
rate of BTBPE was 97.5 ± 6.9% in exposure solution, and 102.9
± 7.9% in larvae, respectively. The sample pretreatment, analysis,
quality assurance, and quality control (QA/QC) are available in the SI (Text S2).

## Whole
Body TH, CRH, and TSH Extraction and
Measurement
Extraction of whole-body larval TH (14 dpf, 200
larvae per sample, n = 4 replicates) was based on
a previous method.23 Details are provided
in SI (Text S3). T4, T3, CRH, and TSH were
measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (T4, T3: Cloud-Clone
Corp, Wuhan, China; CRH, TSH: Keygentec, Nanjing, China) according
to the manufacturer’s instructions. The detection limits for
T4, T3, CRH, and TSH were 1.29 ng/mL, 50.5 pg/mL, 0.5 ng/mL, and 0.2
mU/L, respectively, as indicated by the manufacturer. The intra-assay
variations and the interassay variations reported by the manufacturer
are below 10% and 12% for all hormones, respectively. The hormone
concentrations were normalized against protein content using a commercial
kit utilizing the Bradford method (Keygentec, Nanjing, China).

## RNA Isolation and Quantitative Real-Time
Polymerase Chain Reaction (qRT-PCR) Assay
We measured the
transcription of select genes related to thyroid hormone synthesis,
transport, regulation, and metabolism in the HPT axis of zebrafish
larvae. We used RNAiso Plus (TaKaRa Bio Inc., Japan) to extract total
RNA from homogenized whole larvae fish (14 dpf; 100 larvae; n = 4 replicates). Following previously described protocols,
we extracted and purified total RNA, synthesized first-strand cDNA,
and conducted quantitative real-time PCRs.23 We obtained the primer sequences of the target genes from a previous
study (SI Table S1).23 Real-time PCR results were determined by threshold cycle
(Ct) number and gene transcription levels
were normalized using the 2–ΔΔCt method with β-actin used
as a housekeeping gene.

## Locomotion Behavior Assay
We monitored
spontaneous locomotion and phototaxis. Embryos (22–25 hpf)
were selected and video-recorded for 1 min using a CCD camera (Nikon,
Japan) to count the number of tail swings per embryo as a measure
of spontaneous movement.32 We used 60 embryos
in each treatment group from four replicates for data analysis. We conducted phototaxis assays (swimming from dark to light areas)
at 5 dpf using a previously described method.33 An opaque black acrylic box (10.5 × 3 × 4 cm3 in length × width × height) was separated into chamber
A and chamber B with a sliding partition in the middle. We placed
24 randomly selected larvae per replicate (n = 4
replicates) in chamber B with the partition closed for 5 min under
darkness. After removing the partition, the chamber B remained in
the dark and the chamber A were exposed to 200 lx of ambient light.
After 1 min, we reclosed the partition, subsequently counted zebrafish
in chamber A and B. The chamber structure is provided in SI (Figure S1). We monitored 14 dpf larvae
for the locomotion behavior assay using
the Zebralab Video-Track system (ViewPoint Life Sciences Inc., Montreal,
Canada), following a previous method.32 Normal zebrafish larvae were moved into a 24-well plate (one larvae/well).
Following 5 min of adaptation, we measured larval locomotion in 5
min dark-5 min light-5 min dark cycles and monitored swimming speed
using 48 larvae per treatment from four replicates. The movement frequency
and distance were recorded every 30 s. All locomotion behavior experiments
were conducted at 28 °C.

## Statistical
Analyses
All values are
expressed as mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM). Data were
verified for normality using Shapiro–Wilk’s test and
for homogeneity of variance using Levene’s test. One-way analysis
of variance (ANOVA) with least significant difference (LSD) posthoc
assessed statistical significance. We used SPSS software v22.0 (IBM,
U.S.A.) for statistical analysis and GraphPad Prism 8.0 (Avenida,
CA, U.S.A.) software to generate figures. A p-value
less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

## Results
We used a Ramachandran plot to evaluate the
predicted models (SI Figure S2). The interaction
energies of T3
with TRα and TRβ were −60.16 and −58.2282
kcal/mol, respectively. Furthermore, T3 and TRα hydrogen bonds
were formed with residues GLY315, ARG265, MET296, and HIS418 and between
T3 and TRβ with residues ARG256 and THR312 (Figure S3). Optimal BTBPE conformations with TRα and
TRβ are shown in Figures 1A and 1B. The docking interaction energies
for BTBPE with TRα and TRβ are −36.4005 and −30.6469
kcal/mol, respectively. Figure 1C shows π–π and π-alkyl bonds formed
between BTBPE and TRα with residues HIS193 and ILE390, respectively.
BTBPE interactions with TRβ include π-anion at ASP324
and π-alkyl and alkyl at HIS195, TRP196, and VAL327, respectively

## Zebrafish Larvae
In the 1, 3, and 10 μg/L treatment
groups, the quantified average concentrations of BTBPE were 1.21 ±
0.04, 4.96 ± 0.57, and 8.44 ± 0.16 μg/L, respectively,
upon renewal of exposure solution. After 24 h exposure, the measured
average concentrations of BTBPE were 0.89 ± 0.02, 2.77 ±
0.47, and 3.77 ± 0.38 μg/L. In the 1, 3, and 10 μg/L
treatment groups, BTBPE increased in a concentration-dependent manner,
with average concentrations of 2.61 ± 1.04, 3.16 ± 0.54,
and 5.71 ± 2.96 μg/g d.w. (dry weight) in zebrafish, respectively.
The control group BTBPE concentrations were lower than the detection
limit in both the exposure solution and zebrafish larvae. The hatching
rates did not change at 48, 60, and 72 hpf. Survival and malformation
rates did not change at 120 hpf and body length did not change at
14 dpf. However, all BTBPE treatment groups showed reduced embryonic
heart rates at 36 hpf (Table S2, Figure S5). Exposure to BTBPE reduced T4 concentrations in the 1, 3, and 10
μg/L treatment groups (Figure 4A). The T3 concentration did not remarkably change
(Figure 4B). All treatment

## Quantification
in Exposure Solution and
Zebrafish Larvae
In the 1, 3, and 10 μg/L treatment
groups, the quantified average concentrations of BTBPE were 1.21 ±
0.04, 4.96 ± 0.57, and 8.44 ± 0.16 μg/L, respectively,
upon renewal of exposure solution. After 24 h exposure, the measured
average concentrations of BTBPE were 0.89 ± 0.02, 2.77 ±
0.47, and 3.77 ± 0.38 μg/L. In the 1, 3, and 10 μg/L
treatment groups, BTBPE increased in a concentration-dependent manner,
with average concentrations of 2.61 ± 1.04, 3.16 ± 0.54,
and 5.71 ± 2.96 μg/g d.w. (dry weight) in zebrafish, respectively.
The control group BTBPE concentrations were lower than the detection
limit in both the exposure solution and zebrafish larvae.

## Development Toxicities
The hatching
rates did not change at 48, 60, and 72 hpf. Survival and malformation
rates did not change at 120 hpf and body length did not change at
14 dpf. However, all BTBPE treatment groups showed reduced embryonic
heart rates at 36 hpf (Table S2, Figure S5).

## TH, CRH, and TSH Levels in Zebrafish Larvae
Exposure to BTBPE reduced T4 concentrations in the 1, 3, and 10
μg/L treatment groups (Figure 4A). The T3 concentration did not remarkably change
(Figure 4B). All treatment
groups showed increases in CRH levels (Figure 4C). Concentration of TSH increased in 3 μg/L

## Discussion
Molecular docking explores
the interaction between xenobiotics
and target receptors, determines their toxicological mode of action,29 and was a critical step in determining the affinity
of BTBPE for TRs in this study. BTBPE docked with TR isoforms (i.e.,
TRα and TRβ) by fitting into the active pocket and engaging
in interactions such as π–π stacking, π-anion,
π-alkyl, and alkyl with distinct amino acids. Other BFRs, e.g.,
tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) has been proved to dock with TR-LBD
(ligand binding domain) through π-alkyl, alkyl interactions.34 Having evidence that BTBPE can bind with zebrafish
TRαβ LBD such as T3 suggested that BTBPE was a potential
TR agonist. The in vitro rapid screening assay revealed thyroid
endocrine potential
via TR signaling pathway. In the recombinant TRβ two-hybrid
yeast assay, increased β-galactosidase activity indicated that
BTBPE activates the TR signaling-mediated pathway toward agonistic
activities. The effects of thyroid disruptors, e.g., TBBPA35 and hydroxylated polybrominated biphenyls (OH-PBBs),36 have been demonstrated. We further evaluated
the antagonistic activity of BTBPE when coincubated with T3. Co-administration
of BTBPE with T3 shows a marked inhibition of β-galactosidase
activity relative to T3 treatment, indicating BTBPE disruption of
the thyroid endocrine system through the TR regulatory system. Futhermore,
exposure to BTBPE increased GH3 cell proliferation in the T-Screen
assay, whereas it was inhibited when coexposed with T3, indicating
its agonist potential via TR pathway.37 GH3 cells possess many enzymes, such as TRs, TSH, and deiodinase,
and its proliferation sensitive to T3 level.38,39 Hence, GH3 cell proliferation rate may better predict agonistic/antagonistic
activity of chemicals that have thyroid endocrine potential. The T-Screen
test effectively anticipates the impact of specific chemicals that
disrupt thyroid hormones, including BFRs, polychlorinated biphenyls
(PCBs), and pentachlorophenol, by measuring cell proliferation rate.40,41 We found that both yeast and T-Screening assays are useful for predicting
thyroid endocrine disruption potential via TR-mediated signaling for
BTBPE. Decreased T4 was observed in BTBPE exposure groups, but
not in
the T3. Previous studies have indicated that circulating T3 does not
change with decreased T4 level after exposure to thyroid endocrine-disrupting
chemicals, such as penta-BDEs mixture (DE-71), 2,2′,4,4’5-pentain
polybrominated diphenyl ethers (BDE-99), and decabromodiphenyl ether
(BDE-209),42−44 suggesting that decreased T4 does not limit the T3
supply to the plasma pool, and such regulation mechanism is crucial
for maintaining homeostasis. Studies have shown that the impact of
thyroid endocrine-disrupting activity on T3 levels is unremarkable
compared to its effects on T4 levels in rodents and fish.45,46 This suggests that T4 response is more sensitive than T3 response
to thyroid chemicals stimulation. Increased T4 levels were reported
in bromoacetamide and DE-7147 and NBFRs.
Zebrafish larvae exposure to DBDPE,23 or
3,3′,5,5′-Tetrabromobiphenyl (BB80) for 14 days significantly
increased T4 level.48 The divergence in
reported T4 change may depend on chemical characteristics exposure
time, model species, and exposure route or concentrations. Exposing
zebrafish larvae to DE-71 for 14 days reduces T4, whereas long-term
exposure of DE-71 to adult zebrafish increases T4.42,47 We found that BTBPE is similar to penta-BDE in how it disrupts thyroid
hormones levels. Concentrations of TSH and CRH were increased
via a negative feedback
mechanism regulating the HPT axis, where the secretion of TSH by the
pituitary gland controls the synthesis and release of T4 by the thyroid
follicles. This mechanism allows for response-regulated change in
T4 level. CRH promotes TSH secretion in nonmammalian vertebrates like
amphibians and fish,49 suggesting its potential
role as a universal controller of the thyroidal axis. In this scenario,
elevated CRH and TSH levels are crucial parts of a negative feedback
mechanism that compensates for reduced TH. Hence, we evaluated the
gene transcription profiles associated with the HPT axis, and observed
increased transcription of tg and tpo genes with BTBPE treatment. The transcription of tg and tpo are involved in TH synthesis.50 Zebrafish larvae exposed to various chemical
contaminants (such as BDE-209, DE-71, benzophenone) shown increased
transcription of these genes,accompanied by decreased T4 levels.38,42,44 Other studies have shown decreased tg and tpo gene transcription and increased
T4 levels after exposure to pentabromoethylbenzene.25 Thus, the upregulation of these gene transcription in response
to reduced T4 levels may be compensatory. The ttr gene transcription only decreased in the highest BTBPE exposure
group. The transport of TH involves ttr as does the
regulation of TH supply to different target tissues in fish.51 Derivatives and metabolites of PCBs and phenol
compounds that share a structure similar to THs may influence circulating
TH levels in vertebrates by competing for binding sites on transport
proteins.52 When exposure to BTBPE decreases ttr gene transcription, it reduces the TTR available for
binding to TH. As a result, the unbound T4 is more susceptible to
liver catabolism, increased elimination, and reduced TH circulation.
Similarly, exposure to DE-71 reduced ttr transcription
meanwhile decreasing T4 level.44 We observed
a concentration-dependent upregulation of the ugt1ab gene. Its enzyme activity affects TH metabolism by modifying T4
level, via glucuronidation, for excretion through bile.53 It can decrease TH levels through T4 glucuronidation
in both animal and in vitro models.38 The
BTBPE-triggered increase in ugt1ab transcription
may amplify thyroid hormone elimination, ultimately leading to reduced
TH levels in zebrafish larvae. Deiodinase genes transcription
was decreased in dio2, dio3a, and dio3b, but unchanged
in dio1. Deiodinases regulate TH levels in plasma
and peripheral tissue, and deiodinase gene transcription is influenced
by TH levels in turn.49 For example, higher
levels of TH reduce dio2 transcription and lower
levels increase it.54 In addition, higher
levels of TH increase dio3 transcription whereas
lower levels and normal physiological conditions decrease it. However,
such rules are not entirely consistent with the disruptions caused
by toxicants. For example, in rats exposed to hexachlorobenzene, dio1 increased but circulating T4 and dio2 transcription decreased.55 Walleye (Sander vitreus) treated with endocrine-disrupting chemicals
have elevated dio2 transcription, T3, and
T4 levels, whereas the hepatic mRNA of dio1 and dio3 remained unchanged.56 In
rats given PCB153, T4 dropped and dio2 gene transcription
was suppressed but there was no discernible effect on the dio1 or dio3 genes.57 Other studies found that zebrafish larvae exposed to DBDPE
for 14 days had increased T4 and T3 levels, reduced dio1, and elevated dio2, dio3a, and dio3b gene transcription.23 Gene
transcription of deiodinases occurs in a cell or tissue type-specific
manner suggesting that there is a divergent molecular transcript response
to the thyroid endocrine disruption chemicals. This is more complex
than a secondary reaction to changed TH levels.54,58 We have no evidence if toxicants alter deiodinase activity in TH-targeted
tissues or if deiodinase activity is the primary or secondary result
of toxicant exposure.54 Zebrafish
locomotion is an established end point for evaluating
the effect of environmental pollutants on developmental neurotoxicity.32 Our study indicated that BTBPE causes developmental
neurotoxicity in that it suppresses spontaneous movement, swimming
activity, and visual acuity. This is consistent with another study
indicating that PBDEs exposure can reduce movement and impairs visual
acuity.59 Because TH plays a vital role
in brain development, any disruptions in TH balance may impair neurological
development.60 PBDEs inhibit nervous system
development by altering TH levels.61 Previous
studies have shown that exposure to PBDEs impairs locomotion in embryonic
and larval zebrafish.62 Other studies have
suggested that thyroid hormone signaling participates in early eye
development and regulation of photoreceptor patterns.16,59,63 Hence, thyroid signaling disturbances
caused by BTBPE may disrupt retinal development and neural function.

## Conclusions
This study first determined
that exposure
to BTBPE leads to thyroid
dysfunction and in neurotoxicity in developing fish. For better understanding
of the adverse health impacts and assessing environmental risks of
BTBPE, future research should investigate the BTBPE toxicokinetics
and tissue distribution in organisms, how BTBPE acts on the thyroid
system, and if exposure to environmentally relevant BTBPE concentrations
impacts organism health. In addition, given the critical function
of thyroid hormones in the early development of the central nervous
system, there is also a need to investigate the effects of BTBPE on
neurons.
